statements.name: PROC MDS
statements.description: Multidimensional scaling (MDS) refers to a class of methods. These methods estimate coordinates for a set of objects in a space of specified dimensionality. The input data are measurements of distances between pairs of objects.

arguments.name: ALTERNATE=
arguments.description: Determines what form of alternating-least-squares algorithm is used.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Causes all parameters to be adjusted simultaneously on each iteration.

arguments.name: MATRIX
arguments.description: Adjusts all the parameters for the first subject, then all the parameters for the second subject, and so on, and finally adjusts all parameters that do not correspond to a subject, such as coordinates and unconditional transformations.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Treats subject parameters the same way as the ALTERNATE=MATRIX option but also includes separate stages for unconditional parameters and for subsets of the objects.

arguments.name: COEF=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of matrix for the dimension coefficients.

arguments.name: IDENTITY
arguments.description: Is the default, which yields Euclidean distances.

arguments.name: DIAGONAL
arguments.description: Produces weighted Euclidean distances, in which each subject can have different weights for the dimensions.

arguments.name: CONDITION=
arguments.description: Specifies the conditionality of the data.

arguments.name: UN
arguments.description: (Unconditional) puts all the data into a single partition.

arguments.name: MATRIX
arguments.description: (Matrix conditional) makes each data matrix a partition.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: (Row conditional) makes each row of each data matrix a partition.

arguments.name: CONVERGE=
arguments.description: Sets both the gradient convergence criterion and the monotone convergence criterion to p, where 0 ≤ p ≤ 1. The default is CONVERGE=0.01; smaller values might greatly increase the number of iterations required.

arguments.name: CUTOFF=
arguments.description: Replaces data values less than n with missing values. The default is CUTOFF=0.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS data set containing one or more square matrices to be analyzed.

arguments.name: DECIMALS=
arguments.description: Specifies how many decimal places to use when displaying the parameter estimates and fit statistics. The default is DECIMALS=2.

arguments.name: DIMENSION=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of dimensions to use in the MDS model.

arguments.name: EPSILON=
arguments.description: Specifies a number n, 0 < n < 1, that determines the amount added to squared distances computed from the model to avoid numerical problems such as division by 0.

arguments.name: FIT=
arguments.description: Specifies a predetermined (not estimated) transformation to apply to both sides of the MDS model before the error term is added.

arguments.name: DISTANCE
arguments.description: Fits data to distances. This is the default.

arguments.name: SQUARED
arguments.description: Fits squared data to squared distances.

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Fits log data to log distances.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: Fits nth-power data to nth-power distances. Replace n with actual value.

arguments.name: FORMULA=
arguments.description: Determines how the badness-of-fit criterion is standardized in correspondence with stress formulas 1 and 2 (Kruskal and Wish 1978, pp. 24–26). The default is FORMULA=1 unless you specify FIT=LOG, in which case the default is FORMULA=2.
Fits a regression model by ordinary least squares (Null and Sarle; 1982) without standardizing the partitions.
Standardizes each partition by the uncorrected sum of squares of the (possibly transformed) data; this option should not be used with the FIT=LOG option.
Standardizes each partition by the corrected sum of squares of the (possibly transformed) data; this option is the recommended method for unfolding.

arguments.name: GCONVERGE=
arguments.description: Sets the gradient convergence criterion to p, where 0 ≤ p ≤ 1.

arguments.name: INAV=
arguments.description: Affects the computation of initial coordinates. The default is INAV=DATA.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Computes a weighted average of the data matrices.

arguments.name: SSCP
arguments.description: Estimates missing values in each data matrix and converts each data matrix to a scalar products matrix.

arguments.name: INITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS data set containing initial values for some or all of the parameters of the MDS model. If the INITIAL= option is omitted, the initial values are computed from the data.

arguments.name: LEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the measurement level of the data and hence the type of estimated (optimal) transformations applied to the data or distances (Young 1987, pp. 57–60; Krantz et al. 1971, pp. 9–12) within each partition as specified by the CONDITION= option.

arguments.name: ABSOLUTE
arguments.description: Permits no optimal transformations. Hence, the distinction between regression and measurement models is irrelevant.

arguments.name: RATIO
arguments.description: Fits a regression model in which the distances are multiplied by a slope parameter in each partition (a linear transformation).

arguments.name: INTERVALINT
arguments.description: Fits a regression model in which the distances are multiplied by a slope parameter and added to an intercept parameter in each partition (an affine transformation).

arguments.name: LOGINTERVAL
arguments.description: Fits a regression model in which the distances are raised to a power and multiplied by a slope parameter in each partition (a power transformation).

arguments.name: ORDINAL
arguments.description: Fits a measurement model in which a least-squares monotone increasing transformation is applied to the data in each partition.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations, where n ≥ 0. The default is MAXITER=100.

arguments.name: MCONVERGE=
arguments.description: Sets the monotone convergence criterion to p, where 0 ≤ p ≤ 1, for use with the LEVEL=ORDINAL option. The default is MCONVERGE=0.01

arguments.name: MINCRIT=
arguments.description: Causes iteration to terminate when the badness-of-fit criterion is less than or equal to n, where n ≥ 0. The default is MINCRIT=1E–6.

arguments.name: NEGATIVE
arguments.description: Permits slopes or powers to be negative with the LEVEL=RATIO, INTERVAL, or LOGINTERVAL option.

arguments.name: NONORM
arguments.description: Suppresses normalization of the initial and final estimates.

arguments.name: NOPHIST
arguments.description: Suppresses the output of the iteration history.

arguments.name: NOULB
arguments.description: Causes missing data to be estimated during initialization by the average nonmissing value, where the average is computed according to the FIT= option.

arguments.name: OCOEF
arguments.description: Writes the dimension coefficients to the OUT= data set. See the OUT= option for interactions with other options.

arguments.name: OCONFIG
arguments.description: Writes the coordinates of the objects to the OUT= data set. See the OUT= option for interactions with other options.

arguments.name: OCRIT
arguments.description: Writes the badness-of-fit criterion to the OUT= data set. See the OUT= option for interactions with other options.

arguments.name: OITER
arguments.description: Writes current values to the output data sets after initialization and on every iteration. Otherwise, only the final values are written to any output data sets.

arguments.name: OTRANS
arguments.description: Writes the transformation parameter estimates to the OUT= data set if any such estimates are computed.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Creates a SAS data set containing, by default, the estimates of all the parameters of the PROC MDS model and the value of the badness-of-fit criterion.

arguments.name: OUTFIT=
arguments.description: Creates a SAS data set containing goodness-of-fit and badness-of-fit measures for each partition as well as for the entire data set.

arguments.name: OUTRES=
arguments.description: Creates a SAS data set containing one observation for each nonmissing data value from the DATA= data set.

arguments.name: OVER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum overrelaxation factor, where n ≥ 1. Values between 1 and 2 are generally reasonable. The default is OVER=2 with the LEVEL=ORDINAL, ALTERNATE=MATRIX, or ALTERNATE=ROW option; otherwise, the default is OVER=1. Use this option only if you have convergence problems.

arguments.name: PCOEF
arguments.description: Produces the estimated dimension coefficients.

arguments.name: PCONFIG
arguments.description: Produces the estimated coordinates of the objects in the configuration.

arguments.name: PDATA
arguments.description: Displays each data matrix.

arguments.name: PFINAL
arguments.description: Displays final estimates.

arguments.name: PFIT
arguments.description: Displays the badness-of-fit criterion and various types of correlations between the data and fitted values for each data matrix, as well as for the entire sample.

arguments.name: PFITROW
arguments.description: Displays the badness-of-fit criterion and various types of correlations between the data and fitted values for each row, as well as for each data matrix and for the entire sample. This option works only with the CONDITION=ROW option.

arguments.name: PINAVDATA
arguments.description: Displays the sum of the weights and the weighted average of the data matrices computed during initialization with the INAV=DATA option.

arguments.name: PINEIGVAL
arguments.description: Displays the eigenvalues computed during initialization.

arguments.name: PINEIGVEC
arguments.description: Displays the eigenvectors computed during initialization.

arguments.name: PININ
arguments.description: Displays values read from the INITIAL= data set. Since these values might be incomplete, the PFIT and PFITROW options do not apply.

arguments.name: PINIT
arguments.description: Displays initial values.

arguments.name: PITER
arguments.description: Displays estimates on each iteration.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies options that control the details of the plots. Syntax: PLOTS<(global-plot-option)> <= plot-request <(options)>> PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> <= (plot-request <(options)> <... plot-request <(options)>>)> The global plot option is as follows:

arguments.name: COEFFICIENTS
arguments.description: Combines the INDSCAL coefficients panel of plots into a single plot. By default, the display consists of a panel with two plots. The vectors are displayed in the left plot, and the labels are displayed in the right plot. The right plot provides a magnification of the region of the vector endpoints. In contrast, the single display, requested by COEFFICIENTS(ONE), is more compact, but there is less room for vector labels. It is often easier to identify the vectors in the default display.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all plots.

arguments.name: PTRANS
arguments.description: Displays the estimated transformation parameters if any are computed.

arguments.name: RANDOM=
arguments.description: Causes initial coordinate values to be pseudo-random numbers.

arguments.name: RIDGE=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial ridge value, where n ≥ 0. The default is RIDGE=1E–4.

arguments.name: SHAPE=
arguments.description: Determines whether the entire data matrix for each subject or only one triangle of the matrix is stored and analyzed.

arguments.name: SQUARE
arguments.description: Causes the entire matrix to be stored and analyzed. The matrix can be asymmetric.

arguments.name: TRIANGLE
arguments.description: Causes only one triangle to be stored. However, PROC MDS reads both upper and lower triangles to look for nonmissing values and to symmetrize the data if needed.

arguments.name: SIMILAR=
arguments.description: Causes the data to be treated as similarity measurements rather than dissimilarities.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the singularity criterion p, 0 ≤ p ≤ 1. The default is SINGULAR=1E–8.

arguments.name: UNTIE
arguments.description: Permits tied data to be assigned different optimally scaled values with the LEVEL=ORDINAL option.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement specifies a variable in the DATA= data set that contains descriptive labels for the objects. The labels are used in the output and are copied to the OUT= data set. If there is more than one data matrix, only the ID values from the observations containing the first data matrix are used.

statements.name: INVAR
statements.description: The INVAR statement specifies the numeric variables in the INITIAL= data set that contain initial parameter estimates. The first variable corresponds to the first dimension, the second variable to the second dimension, and so on.

statements.name: MATRIX
statements.description: The MATRIX statement specifies a variable in the DATA= data set that contains descriptive labels for the data matrices or subjects. The labels are used in the output and are copied to the OUT= and OUTRES= data sets. Only the first observation from each data matrix is used to obtain the label for that matrix.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: The VAR statement specifies the numeric variables in the DATA= data set that contain similarity or dissimilarity measurements on a set of objects or stimuli. Each variable corresponds to one object.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement specifies numeric variables in the DATA= data set that contain weights for each similarity or dissimilarity measurement. These weights are used to compute weighted least-squares estimates. The number of WEIGHT variables must be the same as the number of VAR variables, and the variables in the WEIGHT statement must be in the same order as the corresponding variables in the VAR statement.
